You're asking why `TestNGRunner` was added when other people run tests without that class — I'll explain the purpose, when it's useful, what alternatives exist, and give a couple of short examples and recommended next steps.

Checklist
- Explain why `TestNGRunner` exists (purpose + benefits) — Done
- Show common alternatives (IDE/TestNG plugin, testng.xml, Maven/Gradle) — Done
- Give short examples of programmatic and declarative runs — Done
- Recommend what to do next (comment, remove, or keep) — Done

Why this class was created
- `TestNGRunner` is a small helper that programmatically starts TestNG from a regular Java `main` method:
  - Allows you to run TestNG as a plain Java application (e.g., Run -> Java Application in your IDE).
  - Useful for quick local runs and debugging tests without invoking Maven/Gradle or the TestNG plugin.
  - Lets you configure TestNG dynamically (choose classes, suites, listeners, parallelism, output dir, etc.) at runtime.
  - Handy if you need to integrate test execution into another Java program or a custom launcher.

When it's useful
- You want to debug tests in the IDE and step through test code and setup/teardown.
- You need to select tests dynamically (build a list of classes based on runtime data).
- You want to add programmatic listeners or change TestNG configuration before running.
- You don’t want to maintain or edit a `testng.xml` file for ad-hoc runs.

Common alternatives (why others may not have this class)
- testng.xml: declare suites and tests declaratively and run via IDE/TestNG plugin.
- IDE/TestNG plugin: right-click a test class or suite and run — no extra launcher class required.
- Maven/Gradle: `mvn test` or `gradle test` (managed by build tool / surefire / gradle plugin).
- Running test classes directly: if the IDE supports TestNG it can run test classes annotated with `@Test` without a main.

Short examples

1) What your `TestNGRunner` does now (already in your repo)
- It creates a TestNG instance, sets test classes, then runs:
  - testng.setTestClasses(new Class[] { Childclass.class, ParentClass.class });
  - testng.run();

2) Programmatically run a `testng.xml` instead (if you prefer suites)
- Example snippet:
  - testng.setTestSuites(Collections.singletonList("src/test/resources/testng.xml"));
  - testng.run();

3) Run via Maven (no custom launcher needed)
- Use your `pom.xml` and run:
  - mvn test
- (Maven will execute tests through surefire/failsafe using TestNG configuration or annotations.)

Recommendations / next steps
- If you want to keep quick IDE-run / debug capability, keep `TestNGRunner` (maybe add a short javadoc comment above the class to explain its purpose).
- If you prefer using `testng.xml` or Maven and want to reduce clutter, you can remove the file — but only do that if no one depends on the programmatic launcher.
- I can:
  - Add a one-line comment to `TestNGRunner` explaining why it exists, or
  - Remove the file if you'd like, or
  - Convert it to use `testng.xml` programmatically (if that fits your workflow).

Which would you like me to do? If you want, I can add the javadoc comment right now.
